CONTRA COSTA POWER PLANT RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1 BACKGROUND

GenOn (GenOn) owns and operates Contra Costa Generating Station (CCGS), an electric power generating facility located east of Antioch, California, in Contra Costa County.  There are seven existing units at CCGS: Units 1 through 5, which have been retired, and Units 6 and 7, which continue to operate for electric power generation.  In 2001, GenOn began construction of a new combined cycle power generation unit (Unit 8) at the CCGS site.  In 2002, GenOn suspended construction activities associated with Unit 8.  In 2006, ownership of the Unit 8 asset was transferred from GenOn to Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) and has been renamed the Gateway Generating Station by PG&E.

GenOn operates the existing Unit 7 at CCGS with a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system in order to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), as required to comply with Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD) Regulation 9, Rule 11, "Nitrogen Oxides and Carbon Monoxide from Electric Power Generating Steam Boilers."  GenOn began operation of the SCR system for Unit 7 in November of 2001.

The SCR technology utilizes aqueous ammonia to reduce NOx emissions from the generating unit.  The concentration of ammonia in the aqueous solution is 29.4 percent by weight.  This substance is listed as a hazardous material under both California and federal regulations.

To prevent accidental releases of hazardous materials and to reduce their potential impact on the public and the environment, a federal program was established in 1990 as described in Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act.  The California Office of Emergency Services established the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur.  The CalARP Program specifies the regulated substances and determines the requirements f

GenOn's Safety and Health Policy defines GenOn's active commitment to safety and health excellence, compliance with all applicable laws and regulations, the accountability of all employees and contractors and the continuous improvement of its safety and health programs.  Safety is GenOn's number one concern and the Company makes every effort to ensure that employees are trained, equipped and governed in a way that allows them to perform their duties as safely as possible.  GenOn has established extensive safety and health programs and developed manuals, policies, procedures and work practices to document and communicate the purpose, scope, roles and responsibilities and the requirements for these programs in order to create and maintain a safe workplace for everyone.  In order to verify and continuously improve the safety and health programs, GenOn performs regularly scheduled audits, self-assessments and inspections, conducts frequent safety training, and performs incident investigations and hazard assessments.

The release prevention programs implemented in conjunction with this RMP further strengthens the existing environmental, safety and health (ESH) programs at the CCGS. 

1.3 STORAGE AND HANDLING OF REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The only hazardous substance stored and handled onsite at the CCGS in quantities above the federal and CalARP thresholds is aqueous ammonia, which is used in the SCR system to reduce NOx emissions from Unit 7.  GenOn has two 21,200-gallon aqueous ammonia storage tanks.  However, at present, only one of these tanks is used to store aqueous ammonia for the Unit 7 SCR system.  The second storage tank remains empty.  Additionally, there is a third aqueous ammonia storage tank at the CCGS, which was transferred to PG&E's ownership and serves the Gateway Generating Station.

In the SCR system, aqueous ammonia is pumped from the storage tank to a vaporizer which produces a uniform distribution of gaseous amm

onia that is then mixed with the flue gas from the boiler and passed over a catalyst to reduce the NOx emissions from the stack exhaust.

1.3.1	Ammonia Systems
The systems that utilize aqueous ammonia at CCGS are the aqueous ammonia storage facility, the aqueous ammonia vaporization skid, and the ammonia injection grid/SCR reactor. 

1.3.1.1	Aqueous Ammonia Storage Facility
The aqueous ammonia storage facility is located near the northern portion of the developed property of the CCGS, south of Units 6 and 7. This location was selected largely on the basis of safety considerations, because it maximizes the distance from residences, reducing any potential offsite impacts in the event of an accidental release, while minimizing the piping distance to the unit.  In addition, the location was chosen because of the storage facility area's low occupancy, easy access for delivery trucks, adequate distance from combustion equipment, and minimum potential impacts to plant personnel.

The aqueous ammonia storage facility consists of a truck unloading station and three aqueous ammonia storage tanks.  The three storage tanks are made of carbon steel, with capacities of 21,200 gallons each, and dimensions of approximately 10 feet in diameter by 38 feet long.  The storage facility has been designed and constructed to receive and store aqueous ammonia for three different SCR systems: the Unit 7 SCR system that is currently in operation, a planned SCR system for Unit 6 that has not been installed and an SCR system for PG&E's Gateway Generating Station.  At the present time, the aqueous ammonia storage tanks for both the Unit 7 SCR system and for PG&E's Gateway Generating Station are in service.  The aqueous ammonia storage tank that was installed for the Unit 6 SCR system is currently empty.

Although the Unit 7 storage tank has a capacity of 21,200 gallons, the effective maximum volume of the storage tank is limited to 20,000 gallons through administrative controls, which

include operating procedures that require a check of the storage tank level prior to filling the tank to confirm that the tank has sufficient free volume to accept the ammonia delivery without exceeding 20,000 gallons.  The tanks have been designed and constructed in compliance with Uniform Building Code Seismic Zone 4, Uniform Fire Code Article 80, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII, Division 1, Rules for Construction of Pressure Vessels.  The tanks have a maximum design pressure and temperature of 50 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) and 110 degrees Fahrenheit (°F), respectively.

The aqueous ammonia storage tanks are supported horizontally on concrete foundations within a walled containment basin approximately 68 feet long by 44 feet wide that slopes to a centrally located, covered sump beneath the tanks and running the length of the containment area.  This sump is 6 feet wide and 12 feet deep and provides a volume sufficient to hold 100 percent of the contents of one aqueous ammonia storage tank, plus the maximum rainfall recorded in 24 hours in the past 53 years (3.03 inches, WRCC 1955-2008).  Pumps for forwarding the aqueous ammonia to the SCR systems and for unloading aqueous ammonia from delivery tanker trucks are also located within the containment basin.

Aqueous ammonia is delivered to CCGS via tanker truck.  Individual tanker trucks can transport up to 6,500 gallons of aqueous ammonia.  The concrete slab at the truck unloading station has been designed to contain the contents of one full tanker truck and is sloped to quickly drain any accidental releases of aqueous ammonia into the central covered containment sump.  Each storage tank has an unloading station consisting of an ammonia fill line, where aqueous ammonia is fed from the delivery truck to the tank, and a vapor return line where vapor pressure between the tank and the truck is equalized. 

1.3.1.2	Aqueous Ammonia Vaporization Skid
The aqueous

ammonia is pumped through three-quarter-inch, stainless-steel piping from the storage tanks to the SCR injection grid.  The portion of the piping between the storage tank containment area and the Unit 7 SCR injection grid that crosses the roadway and parking areas is contained within a covered trench that protects the piping from vehicular traffic and provides secondary containment.  The section of piping between the storage tank containment area and the covered trench and the section of piping that exits the covered trench and delivers aqueous ammonia to the SCR injection grid is contained within larger-diameter polyvinyl chloride (PVC) piping for all stretches as per the request of the Contra Costa County Fire Protection District (CCCFPD).  Therefore, secondary containment is provided for all sections of aqueous ammonia piping.

The aqueous ammonia delivery and injection facilities for the Unit 7 SCR system include two aqueous ammonia feed pumps, ammonia vaporization equipment, and an ammonia injection grid.  In the SCR system, aqueous ammonia is pumped from the storage tank to spray nozzles inside the ammonia vaporizer unit that is mounted on the vaporizer skid near the SCR reactor.  The spray droplets are then mixed with a hot air diluent stream in the vaporizer to evaporate the ammonia and water.  The vaporizer produces a uniform distribution of gaseous ammonia in the diluent stream.  The diluent stream is then transported to the injection grid.

1.3.1.3	Ammonia Injection Grid / SCR
The ammonia injection grid provides additional mixing of the diluent stream and transports it to the SCR reactor.  The SCR reactor converts much of the ammonia and oxides of nitrogen from the flue gas into nitrogen gas and water, which are released from the stack.

The injection grid is located upstream of the SCR reactor.  This allows more thorough mixing of the ammonia-laden diluent stream with the turbulent flue gas from the boiler.  Although the oxidation-reduction reacti

on is initiated by the injection of ammonia at the injection grid, the reaction is completed in the SCR reactor by passing the mixture over a catalyst composed primarily of titanium and vanadium oxides.  The treated flue gas, containing a small amount of unreacted NOx and ammonia, is then discharged out of the stack.

The SCR process is controlled with feed-forward and feedback control loops.  An upstream NOx analyzer measures the NOx concentration prior to the SCR reactor inlet.  A downstream analyzer measures the NOx concentration downstream of the SCR reactor outlet.  The ammonia demand signal, which regulates the rate at which aqueous ammonia is pumped to the vaporizer, is determined from both NOx analyzers.
 
1.3.2	Aqueous Ammonia Hazards
The aqueous ammonia solution that is used for the Unit 7 SCR system at CCGS is 29.4 percent ammonia by weight, with water making up the balance of the solution.  Aqueous ammonia is a corrosive material, although the degree of danger associated with the substance is considered to be minor.  Ammonia is not a known carcinogen, but it poses acute and chronic non-carcinogenic health hazards to the respiratory system and chronic non-carcinogenic health hazards as skin irritations or other effects.  Acute health hazards are those that occur from short exposures to airborne ammonia vapor, whereas chronic health effects are those that occur as a result of long-term exposures.

Although there is some insoluble ammonia present in the ammonia solution; the solution has a very low vapor pressure compared to anhydrous ammonia, a more hazardous compound that is also used for SCR systems.  Ammonia vapor is irritating at levels above a few ppmv and acutely toxic in high concentrations.  A 1-hour average ammonia vapor concentration above 200 ppmv could cause respiratory irritation to exposed individuals. 

Ammonia vapor is flammable in air at concentrations of 16 percent to 25 percent, but requires a very high temperature source for ig

nition.  Ammonia concentrations directly above an aqueous ammonia spill never approach these concentrations; therefore, aqueous ammonia has no explosive flammability potential.

1.4	MANAGEMENT SYSTEM
GenOn is dedicated to reducing any risks associated with the storage and handling of the aqueous ammonia for the SCR systems at CCGS.  To support GenOn's strict goal of accident-free operation, a management system has been developed to oversee the implementation of the various RMP program elements.  In this management system, the Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP program elements.  An organizational chart showing the titles of those positions assigned responsibility for implementing the individual RMP program elements and defining the lines of authority has been developed.  Each position having responsibility for the different RMP program elements reports changes that affect the RMP to the Plant Manager, who ensures that all affected elements of the RMP are updated appropriately and that the local Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA) is kept abreast of all changes to the RMP.  Changes to RMP program elements are communicated to all other positions having responsibility for RMP program elements during regularly scheduled meetings, including daily tailboard meetings and weekly staff meetings.  RMP program element changes that include revisions to procedures, plans or policies, training, hazard reviews, and changes to drawings or other documents are also communicated during staff meetings or through project coordination and design review meetings.  The individual RMP program elements, such as training, emergency response, etc., are outlined in this RMP. 

To ensure continued compliance with the CalARP regulations, GenOn will update this RMP within 5 years of the most recent update, before any additional regulated substance is brought onsite, before additional aqueous ammonia storage is installed

, or if there is a major change that may alter the offsite consequence analysis.  At CCGS, records supporting the different aspects of the RMP are maintained for at least 5 years.  Documents and records pertaining to safety information, hazard reviews, and maintenance are retained for the life of the process.

The concentration of aqueous ammonia is not high enough to be regulated by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, which only regulates aqueous ammonia solutions with concentrations of 44 percent by weight or greater. 

1.5	CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS  
Safety was the foremost consideration when designing the aqueous ammonia storage facility.  The location of the aqueous ammonia storage facility was selected to be in a low occupancy area of the plant and at a maximum distance from the property fenceline to reduce potential onsite and offsite impacts from a spill.

The aqueous ammonia storage tanks are enclosed within a walled containment basin that slopes to a centrally located, covered sump beneath the tanks, which runs the length of the containment area.  There also is a walled containment pad at the tanker truck unloading facility that drains rapidly into the covered sump under the tanks in the event of a spill.

Many accident prevention safeguards have been implemented within the aqueous ammonia storage area.  For example, in the event of a power outage, standby power needed for all required electrical systems, such as monitors and alarms, is provided by the Uninterruptible Power Supply system.  Also, hot work permits are required for specific activities that present the potential for fire, and personnel involved in such operations have received appropriate training. 

Other safety features of the aqueous ammonia storage facility include:
 
    - Ammonia area monitoring system with audible and visible alarms;
    - Eyewash and shower stations;
    - Piping and connections

1.6.1	Safety Information
The only toxic chemical addressed in this RMP is aqueous ammonia at a concentration of 29.4 percent by weight in water.  The aqueous ammonia is used in the liquid state as a reagent for the Unit 7 SRC system.  There are a total of three 21,200-gallon carbon steel aqueous ammonia storage tanks.  One of the three storage tanks, including the associated pumps, pipes and control systems, has been transferred to PG&E's ownership and serves the Gateway Generating Station.  GenOn utilizes one of the ammonia storage tanks for the Unit 7 SCR system.  The other GenOn storage tank is not currently used and remains empty.

The aqueous ammonia is heated and vaporized prior to injection into the boiler exhaust stream, where it reacts with a catalyst to reduce NOx emissions.  The potential health risks associated with aqueous ammonia are discussed in Section 1.3.2.

GenOn has developed an extensive safety program to reduce the risks associated with the handling of hazardous materials such as aqueous ammonia.  The purpose of the safety program is to protect GenOn employees, neighbors, and the Antioch community from health risks associated with the operation of the CCGS.  The development, distribution, and implementation of the SCR process safety information are critical to proper and safe operation of the system.  Compilation of safety information (related to aqueous ammonia, the process and the process equipment) is beneficial to release prevention because it enables personnel to identify, understand and mitigate hazards posed by the SCR system.

The program applies to the CCGS site only.  The potential for serious accidental releases is greatly reduced by maintaining a strong safety program.  Key aspects of this program are described in the remainder of this section.  Personnel that work with the aqueous ammonia system utilize the safety program by attending annual safety training classes and always have access to safety informat

ion such as procedures for the Lockout/Tagout and Confined Space programs, and other safety practices via the computer network.  Safety information pertaining to aqueous ammonia, the SCR system and its ancillary equipment is also described in the Aqueous Ammonia/SCR Safety Information Binder, which is maintained at CCGS. MSDSs for aqueous ammonia and other hazardous materials can be accessed in electronic or hard copy form through the 3E Corporation and are also maintained in hardcopy form at CCGS.  Safety training records are documented and kept onsite for 5 years.

GenOn has ensured that the SCR systems at CCGS have been designed and constructed in compliance with applicable and recognized codes and standards.  This was achieved with thorough reviews of design drawings and equipment specifications, shop inspections and testing of critical equipment and components, and field testing and inspections performed by outside parties.  

The aqueous ammonia storage tanks comply with Uniform Building Code Seismic Zone 4, Uniform Fire Code Article 80, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII, Division 1, "U" Stamp, Rules for Construction of Pressure Vessels.  The tanks have a maximum design pressure and temperature of 50 psig and 110°F, respectively and a minimum design temperature of -20°F. 

The piping from the aqueous ammonia storage tank to the SCR reactor is constructed to the ANSI/ASME B31.1 standard.  The expected maximum flow rate of aqueous ammonia from the storage tanks to the vaporizers under 100 percent load is 35 gallons per hour for Unit 7.  The vaporizer is designed to operate within a temperature range of 0 to 750°F, a pressure range of  14.7 to 10 psig, with an air flow up to 6000 pounds per hour and a maximum aqueous ammonia flow of 250 pounds per hour.  The vaporizer is built of 316 stainless steel , to the ANSI/ASME B31.1 standard.

Changes to the safety program may be made at the discretion of the Safety Engineer on an as-needed basis, but are typically made as a result of system modifications, incident investigations, issues raised in daily safety tailboard meetings, or directives from the Safety Committee. 1.6.2	Hazard Revi

ew
As part of the update to change the existing RMP from Program I to Program II, a hazard review was performed.  The hazard review utilized a multi-discipline team to systematically examine the aqueous ammonia process in order to identify the hazards associated with the design, operation and maintenance of the process and to evaluate the adequacy of the existing safeguards that are in place to mitigate the hazards.  Where the existing safeguards were determined to be inadequate, the hazard review team identified recommendations to further mitigate the hazards that were identified.

After reviewing the available methodologies and approaches for conducting the hazard review and consulting with CCCHSD, the What-If checklist method was selected for the hazard review.  The What-If checklist approach was selected for its simplicity and its versatility to be customized to the appropriate level of detail and analysis needed for the aqueous ammonia process.  A What-If checklist was developed for the aqueous ammonia process and was utilized by the hazard review team to identify and evaluate the hazards associated with the use and handling of aqueous ammonia in the aqueous ammonia process, applicable external events including seismic events that could result in an accidental release of aqueous ammonia and potential equipment malfunctions or human errors that could cause a release of aqueous ammonia.  The hazard review team also analyzed and evaluated the  existing safeguards, including process controls, administrative controls and monitoring/detection systems that are in place to prevent or mitigate an accidental release of aqueous ammonia.  This included a review and evaluation of the items listed in Exhibits 7.4 D,E,F,G & H from Appendix H of the Contra Costa County CalARP Program Guidance Document.  For cases where the existing safeguards were determined to be inadequate, the hazard review team identified recommendations and action items for improvements or further stud

review for inherently safer systems.

The complete documentation of the hazard review are maintained on site.

1.6.3	Operating Procedures
The CCGS Operations Supervisor is responsible for the development, implementation, and updating of the operating procedures at CCGS.  The purpose of these operating procedures is to ensure that plant operations are performed in an appropriate, safe, and consistent manner.  These operating procedures apply to operations at CCGS only.  The main objective of the operating procedures is to provide a written description of correct methods for performing work-related tasks to GenOn operations personnel.  Well developed and properly implemented operating procedures ensure that tasks are performed correctly, safely, and with the appropriate frequency.  Clearly, adherence to good operating procedures reduces the risk of incidents including accidental releases.  The operating procedures for the SCR system were developed from design documents, operation and maintenance manuals, equipment manufacturer manuals, ammonia supplier procedures and guidelines as well as from the input from experienced operators during reviews of the procedures and during the Hazard Review meetings.  The operating procedures are reviewed annually by operations personnel to ensure that the procedures are current and accurate and any discrepancies that are identified are corrected.  The procedures are then certified by the Operations Supervisor to be current and accurate.  All operators are encouraged to provide suggestions for improvements to the operating procedures to the Operations supervisor at any time.  All operating procedures are maintained on the company network, so that all employees can easily access the most current version of the procedures from any computer at the plant.  Printed copies of the current procedures are also kept in the plant control room.  The operating procedures are also updated whenever a major change to the SCR systems occurs and b

introduced into their work area that they have not previously been trained in.

Information and training may be designed to cover categories of hazards (e.g. flammability, carcinogenicity) or specific chemicals.  Chemical-specific information must always be available through labels and MSDSs.  Employees are informed of any operations in their work area where hazardous chemicals are present, and of the location and availability of the written hazard communication program, including the required list of hazardous chemicals, and the required MSDSs.

The SCR Training Program Manual, which resides at the CCGS, informs employees about the equipment used with the SCR system, the controls and operations involved with the SCR system, how to conduct routine maintenance, how to troubleshoot problems in the system, and how to safely operate and handle the system.

Initial training at the CCGS includes at least the following:
    - Methods and observations that may be used to detect the presence or release of a hazardous chemical
      in the work area;
    - The physical and health hazards of the chemicals in the work area;
    - The measures employees can take to protect themselves from the hazards, such as appropriate work
      practices, emergency procedures, and personal protective equipment (PPE) used; and
    - The hazard communication program, including an explanation of the labeling system and MSDSs, and
      how employees can obtain and use the appropriate hazard information.
Initial and refresher training are documented through personnel training session sign-in sheets.

All Generating Station Technicians (Operations, Electrical & Mechanical Maintenance, Support Services, and Technical Services) and ESH personnel receive annual refresher training, or more frequent training if necessary, about emergency response plans and relevant safety and health issues.  Additional hazardous materials training is conducted for personnel working directly with the a

queous ammonia systems. 

Training is conducted whenever:
    - The job presents identified hazards;
    - Changes in job assignment impact hazard exposures;
    - New or previously unidentified hazards are identified as part of the job;
    - Work procedures or practices are developed or changed that may produce new hazards; and
    - New substances, equipment, or tools are introduced that may present a hazard.

Training is conducted whenever:

    - Work procedures or practices are developed or changed that may produce new hazards; and

1.6.5	Contractor Management
To ensure that contractors that work for GenOn are adequately trained, the following policies are implemented at the CCGS:
    - As part of the contractual arrangement between any outside contractor and GenOn, the contractor is
      responsible for complying with OSHA Hazard Communication regulations and the GenOn Hazard 
      Communication Plan.  Contractors are required to make available, upon request, a copy of their
      current Hazard Communication Plan.
    - Contractors working on GenOn company property must be notified by GenOn of hazardous chemicals to
      which contractor's employees may be exposed, and appropriate control measures needed to limit such
      exposure.  Contractors must be notified of the location and contents of the GenOn site hazard
      communication plan.  Proper controls must be established to ensure that GenOn operations do not
      expose the contractor's employees to known safety and health hazards.  Contractors must be notified
      of precautionary measures to protect themselves while on the job and in the event of an emergency
     (e.g., alarms, evacuation routes, etc.).

- Copies of MSDSs for all chemicals the contractor's employees may be exposed to are provided to the
      contractor upon request.  Likewise, all contractors are required to furnish GenOn with MSDSs for
      all hazardous chemicals that are planned to be brought on site upon request, prior to bringing the
      chemicals on site.

1.6.6	Maintenance
The Maintenance Supervisor is responsible for the aqueous ammonia system maintenance program, which includes implementing, recording, and updating the program.  Maintenance procedures are available from the Maintenance Supervisor at CCGS.  Maintenance records are maintained for the life of the process.  The majority of the procedures were obtained or developed from equipment manuals and vendors.  The Maintenance Supervisor reviews the maintenance procedures annually to ensure that they are current and accurate.  The training coordinator is responsible for making sure that all relevant personnel are trained in the respective maintenance procedures.  The purpose of the maintenance program is to ensure that plant structures and equipment are kept in optimal working condition.  This maintenance program applies to structures and equipment at the CCGS only.  The objectives of the maintenance program are to facilitate scheduled inspections of plant structures and equipment, enable plant personnel to recognize abnormalities in the appearance or functionality of these structures and equipment, and to prompt repairs or other actions as a result of the inspections.  A well developed and implemented maintenance plan ensures that structures and equipment are kept in good operating condition and do not pose health risks due to lack of maintenance.  Clearly, adherence to good maintenance program reduces the risk of incidents including accidental releases.  All personnel involved with the maintenance of the SCR systems have been trained and records of the training are maintained.

Maintenance of major SCR equipment is perfor

med on vendor-recommended basis and inspections are conducted in a timely manner.  Additionally, GenOn periodically inspects the integrity of the structural components of the process.  These inspections include:
    - Annual visual inspection of the storage tank and tank foundation;
    - Non-destructive evaluation (NDE) of the storage tank every 5 years, or more frequent depending on
      results of the last NDE;
    - Annual inspections of the piping and pipe supports; and
    - Periodic inspections of the containment sump.

The periodic equipment and structural component inspections are conducted by qualified personnel and documented in the company computer-based maintenance tracking system.  Each inspection record includes, at minimum, the date of the inspection, the name of the component inspected, and the person who performed the inspection.

Existing administrative requirements for the maintenance program at the CCGS include periodic inspections, inspection review, inspection follow-up (planning and repair), and recordkeeping. Trained personnel perform the periodic inspections.  Inspection findings are reviewed by the Maintenance Supervisor who determines if any follow-up action (such as equipment repair or replacement) is required.  Maintenance of SCR components are accomplished in accordance with the guidelines of the SCR vendor manuals.  Other maintenance procedures are developed by the Maintenance Supervisor. Recordkeeping of maintenance and inspections are prompted and organized within SAP.

1.6.7	Compliance Audits
Compliance audits motivate employees to thoroughly follow safe operating and maintenance procedures as well as uncovering shortcomings of these procedures and providing a formal structure in which to address these shortcomings.  Improving the employee motivation and the quality of the procedures used by employees will reduce the probability of an accident.  To ensure that the procedures and practices outlined above are adequate an

d being followed, a compliance audit shall be conducted at least every 3 years.  In addition to reviewing the operating and maintenance procedures and practices for adequacy, the compliance audit evaluates all of the prevention program elements to ensure that they are functioning properly.  The compliance audit shall be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  GenOn assigns the responsibility for this audit to the Environmental Department.  A report shall be created that addresses any deficiencies, along with suggested solutions.  The two most recent compliance audit reports shall be retained onsite, though this does not apply to any compliance audit report that is more than 5 years old.

The developed compliance audit program satisfies the regulatory requirements of Section 2755.6 of the CalARP regulation.  The compliance audit team training includes the imparting of a thorough understanding of the CalARP regulations and a review of the Guidance for Auditing Risk Management Plans/Programs.  Although this guidance is intended for regulators, the checklist in Annex C of the Guidance document is followed.  The compliance audits shall be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.

To ensure that all aspects of the RMP program have been implemented correctly, two different programs have been implemented, as described below:
    - GenOn's Compliance Audit Program - GenOn's Corporate Audit Department performs periodic ESH
      audits.  The purpose of these audits is to assess the overall adequacy of the ESH programs and
      management system and to provide a reasonable assurance of compliance with all applicable
      regulations and Company requirements.  Corporate audits involve visual walk-downs of the facility,
      as well as interviews with management, operations and maintenance personnel.  A Detailed Audit
      Report is prepared with audit findings and management responses for corrective actions, due dates

and responsible persons.
    - Facility Walk-down Assessments - In-house assessments are conducted by walk-downs of the various
      systems and facilities, noting any hazardous conditions or housekeeping issues.  These are
      performed by teams of plant personnel and contractors when applicable.  These walk-down assessments
      are performed more frequently during periods of heavy activity such as maintenance outages.  Issues
      identified during the walk-downs are either resolved immediately or work orders are created to
      address the issues.

The Plant Manager at CCGS ensures the implementation of the recommendations from the audits, or at a minimum, assesses each recommendation to ensure it can be implemented at the CCGS.

1.6.8	Incident Investigation
The Plant Manager at the CCGS is ultimately responsible for all aspects of an incident investigation.  Incident investigations are conducted whenever a catastrophic release of a hazardous substance occurs that requires an agency notification or results in injuries or illnesses that require medical attention.  Incident investigations are also conducted for near misses that could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of a hazardous material or a potential injury or illness.  The primary purpose of the incident investigation is to identify the underlying root causes of the incident, and to develop and implement corrective actions to prevent the incident or similar incidents from recurring.  Incident reports are distributed to all GenOn facilities to reduce repeat occurrences and share lessons learned.  The incident investigation program at the CCGS is beneficial to release prevention by ensuring that any incident or potential incident will not be repeated, thus reducing the chance of future incidents.

All incidents requiring an investigation, including near-miss incidents are reported immediately to the appropriate department supervisor.  The department supervisor will le

ad the investigation and prepare the incident report or delegate the responsibility to another department or employee.  Depending on the severity and complexity of the incident, additional employees with specific knowledge of and experience with the design, operation, and/or maintenance of the process will participate in the investigation.  Contract employees will also participate in the investigation if they were involved in the incident.  If the incident involves a recordable incident, or a serious or fatal injury or illness, the Safety and Health department representative also performs an investigation.  The determination as to the seriousness of the incident is left to the discretion of the Safety and Health representative. 

The department supervisor or delegated employee leading the investigation is required to initiate the incident investigation as soon as possible, but not later than 48 hours after the incident has occurred.  At the conclusion of the investigation, a written summary of the investigation is prepared on an Incident Report form.  This report form includes the date of the incident, a description of the incident, corrective actions taken, the root cause(s) and other factors contributing to the incident, and recommendations from the investigation to prevent recurrence.  The Incident Reports are retained on site for a minimum of 5 years. 

The Plant Manager determines what actions are to be taken to prevent recurrence of future incidents of this type.  The Plant Manager is responsible for implementing these actions and for informing all employees, including contractors who are affected by the recommendation and findings of the investigation.

1.7	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
During the past 5 years at the facility, there have been no accidents involving regulated substances or other extremely hazardous substances that have resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelte

ring in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Accidents at the CCGS have been avoided by adhering to the safety and environmental programs listed in Section 1.2, continually improving the personnel safety training program and adhering to a strict maintenance program for all equipment involved with the storage and handling of hazardous substances.

1.8	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The CCGS has coordinated emergency response programs with the CCCHSD and the CCCFPD.  As part of this coordination of the emergency response programs, the CCGS will conduct drills with the CCCFPD and CCCHSD.  GenOn recently conducted Confined Space Rescue training and drills at the CCGS with CCCFPD.  Also, as part of the update of the RMP for the CCGS from Program I to Program II, and with the shared operation of the ammonia storage facility with PG&E's Gateway Generating Station, the CCGS will be conducting a coordinated emergency response drill with PG&E, CCCHSD and CCCFPD for a simulated ammonia release.  Periodically, the fire department inspects the facilities that store and handle flammable hazardous materials at CCGS to ensure that the applicable Uniform Fire Code requirements are being met. The Hazardous Materials Programs Division of CCCHSD also conducts inspections of facilities that store and handle hazardous materials in order to evaluate compliance with hazardous materials regulations. 

In the unlikely event of an accidental release of a hazardous substance, the CCGS utilizes an alphanumeric paging system as its primary emergency notification system for all onsite personnel.  The system provides written information regarding the emergency.  If the release could result in an offsite public health concern, the emergency coordinator or incident commander shall notify Contra Costa County officials to determine if the community warning system (CWS) should be activated.  All community notifications, whether initiated manually or automatically, are coordinated with t

he CCCFPD. 

The above notification procedures are explained in detail in the Facility Emergency Plan along with procedures for minimizing the impact of an incident, appropriate response activities for each hazardous substance onsite, and the phone numbers to contact both on and offsite emergency response personnel.  A copy of the Facility Emergency Plan is kept onsite.  The Facility Emergency Plan is updated and employees are retrained as new substances or emergency procedures are implemented at the CCGS facility and an update log is maintained within the Plan.  The Facility Emergency Plan and Hazardous Materials Business Plan has been submitted and coordinated with CCCHSD.  The Contra Costa County Hazardous Materials Area Plan has been reviewed and is maintained at the CCGS for use during a hazardous materials incident that could affect human health or the environment.   

CCGS personnel that can respond to an incidental release have successfully completed training in respiratory protection, hazard communication, Emergency Action Plan, use of PPE and decontamination procedures.

1.9	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
It is GenOn's goal to operating a safe, accident-free facility.  To that end, the safety features described in previous sections of this document have been implemented.  Regular equipment inspections, maintenance, and safety reviews help ensure continued safe operations at the CCGS.

Several planned changes to improve safety came out of the hazard review process, the seismic assessment, and the security and vulnerability assessment (SVA).  These assessments produced lists of recommendations aimed at improving safety.  Some of the recommendations called for an assessment of the benefits and practicalities of implementing a recommended change.  Some of the recommendation evaluations concluded that the proposed change was not necessary either because existing safeguards were considered adequate, the added safety offered by the change did not warr

ant the cost of the change, implementing the change was not practical, or other reasons.  

In addition to developing recommendations for changes to improve safety, the Hazard Review, seismic assessment, and SVA identified items that require further investigation.  One such example that was a product of the seismic assessment is to evaluate the pipe supports for the carbon steel vent piping that is connected to the discharge side of the storage tank safety relief valves for adequacy.  The items requiring further investigation and the status of those items can also be found in the Program Manual.
As an ongoing measure to evaluate and improve safety GenOn California's Safety Committee meets at least four times a year to review and develop the safety and health programs for GenOn's Generating Stations.
